awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Group-Centric Secure Information Sharing - Models, Properties, and Implementation
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the oldest and most challenging problems in cyber security is to enable secure information sharing (SIS) (i.e., maintaining some control over information even after it has been shared.)  For example, a product manufacturer may need to share customer account information with a company that ships the products and bills the customers.  The manufacturer cannot allow its partner to then misuse those customer records by direct marketing or selling customer records. This project focuses on the policy challenge of specifying, analyzing and enforcing SIS policies. The project is developing intuitive, usable, and mathematically sound models that can be used by organizations to specify and enforce SIS policies.

This project focuses on specifying, analyzing and enforcing group-centric secure information sharing (g-SIS) policies. The researchers are developing a theory of multiple, connected groups based on relationships such as subordination, conditional membership and mutual exclusion, with broad, real-world application. The approach separates policy layer specifications from enforcement layer specifications, and develops varying levels of formal consistency metrics between the two with respect to authorization decisions.  The research team is working with organizations to prototype and use the information sharing platform in ongoing community cyber incident information sharing efforts.

por.por_cntn:
The need to share information using computer systems while retaining control over it is one of the oldest and most challenging problems in cyber security. Organizations often need to share information with that of others for the purpose of collaboration while maintaining control over such information.  This problem has only compounded over the last decades with the advancement and proliferation of information technology. At the same time, our increasingly information-rich and information-dependent society needs to leverage secure information sharing to fully benefit from the productivity, and social and national security benefits of the ongoing cyber revolution.  The central goal of this project was to develop intuitive, usable, and mathematically sound models that can be used by organizations for secure information sharing.

Following are the major outcomes from the research conducted in this project:

(a) We find that "group-centric" is a viable structure for sharing information in the context of cyber threat intelligence sharing scenarios.

(b) We find that machine learning based access control (MLBAC) is a viable form of access control and that it provides significant advantages over classical approaches. MLBAC is good fit for information sharing for cyber intelligence.

(c) We developed practical techniques for sharing information with third parties while maintaining control over what could be learned by such parties. This enables sharing information while preserving privacy over certain aspects of the information that was shared.

We anticipate that outcomes will no-doubt have significant impact in the future. Our society is becoming increasingly connected thereby facilitating automation of some of the basic and advanced tasks. A secure and end-user controllable connected digital space is paramount for the current and future society. Ransomware attacks are on the rise as evidenced by the recent news reports. By developing secure cyber threat information sharing models between various organizations, we expect that these outcomes will facilitate functioning of a safe society. Furthermore, government and industry seek well-trained and talented human resources who can help mitigate this issue. By the training students to conduct research in the multi-disciplinary field of secure cyber threat information sharing, we expect that the outcomes from this project will make a significant impact in the field of science and technology and contribute to workforce development in this area.
